titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Endeavouring again to be industrious. Wrote the principal part of the morning. Walk again in the wood. All the afternoon and Evening at home. Arrears of Tibullus repaired; Paradise Lost again taken up.

2. Mr: Waldo, Mr: Broome, Mr: Howel here this morning: last from Amsterdam. Went with them to Scheveling; to the House in the wood &c. they went on to Rotterdam in the afternoon. Captain Phillips and Captain Loring here also, to request (the former) a certificate from me which I gave him. Met and walk’d with Bielfeld in the Voorhout this Evening.— No writing this day.
3. Repairing partially the losses of time. Called on Bielfeld. Went with him to the play. Performance indifferent as heretofore. Saw the books proposed for sale next week.

4. Rainy, drizly day. Walk in the forenoon. Met and walk’d with Mr: Midleton. Bielfeld called on me. Went with him to Baron Schubart’s, he & his lady both out. Met them, and also Mr: Levsen soon after at Mr: Scholtens; who as well as Madam is unwell. returns into town to morrow. Madam Schubart, the most decidedly anti-patriote that I have met with. Retired soon, with Bielfeld. My brother return’d this evening from his jaunt to Amsterdam & Rotterdam.
5. Attended the sale of books, and made some purchases. Walk in the wood towards Evening. Letter to America.

6. Attended the sale again. Visit from Mr: Houghton, upon his business; which is not
yet settled. Called on Mr: Van Son.— He enquired if I could supply him with the signature of the President of the United States, and of my father, in their own hand writing. He wanted them for one of his friends, who had taken pains to procure similar signatures to annex upon the portraits contained in the Vaderlansche Historie. The collection is almost complete, but he still wants those two. I told him I could only satisfy him in part. Walk in the morning: whole Evening at home. Visit from an English Lady.

7. Sale again diligently attended. Met Mr: Levsen & Bielfeld there. Walk with the former at the Society usually between 1. & 3. Visit from an Emigrant Lady to demand a Passport: very much offended that I refused to give it. Evening at Mlle: Laurenzi’s. Company generally the same and cards as customary.

8. At the sale. Walk with Mr: Levsen. met Mr: Midleton. Levsen told me that he sent the Emigrant Lady to me yesterday as she told him she was an American. Rec’d newspapers and letters from England and America. Bielfeld here part of the Evening.

9. Sale again. Mr: Houghton’s business still pendent. Called on Bielfeld; and walk with him.— Rains at present almost every day.— Evening reading Centinels. The agent of the States General was at my lodgings, to announce verbally to me from their High Mightinesses in answer to my last memorial, that the Embargo was removed last week. I was out and did not see him.
10. Called this morning to see Mr: Paulus. He was out of town, to return on Monday. Mr: Houghton returns to Amsterdam. Walk in the forenoon, & towards Evening. Reading Milton as yet.
11. Walking in the morning; and towards night. Went to see Mr: Dumas. Madam unwell. found Mr: Veerman with his family had returned from the Country. Remainder of the Evening there.

12. Went again this morning to see Mr: Paulus. Conversation with him, relative to Houghton’s business; and to that of Mr: Loring of a similar kind. He appeared well disposed: more perhaps than he really was. Accounts of a new explosion at Paris.— Play. French company returned. Le Maitre Genereux. Music of Paësiello. of course excellent. Les Vendangeurs. badly performed.

13. Letter from the bankers at Amsterdam, with a bill on the Treasurer of the States General, which they request me to present. Saw Mr: N. van Staphorst, and Mr: Abbema. the bill not accepted. Saw likewise at 4. The french Representative
Ramel on the subject. He assured me the bill would be paid. Dined at Baron Schubart’s: arrived late. The french Representative Richard; the Minister Noël, and the usual other company there. The frenchmen did not appear much affected by the late tragical events at Paris; they seemed to receive more pleasure from the victory than affliction from the struggle. Richard said that Paris was a child that had to beat its mother, and been whipped for it, till it fetched blood. Noel said that the issue was fortunate, though it was to be regretted, that considering that french blood only had been shed in the contest.
At the play. La fausse Agnes with Philippe at Georgette. The latter a little opera, music good. New performers, superior to those that we have had hitherto.

14. Received this morning from the Secretary of State, a letter, dated August 14. containing orders to repair without delay to London where I shall find directions and documents for my government. Sent to Rotterdam to enquire when the vessel going from thence to England will be ready to sail. This business is unpleasant and unpromising, but I have no election.
Evening at Mlle: Lorenzi’s. fortunate at a Lottery. prize which could be of little service to me. Play’d at whist. Reuterswerd there but a short time.

15. Obliged to spend a considerable part of the day in arranging books. Solitary walk. Evening at the play. Coquette corrigée, very good. Ambroise ou voila ma journée, an opera music of d’Alayrac, and as usual the only part of the composition that deserved notice.

16. Mr: Allis breakfasted with us this morning. Says he expects to go next week to England Tuesday or Wednesday. Tilly returned home, having gone through the small pox. Bielfeld called on me. Walk with him in the wood.— Communicative with him sometimes beyond proper discretion: perhaps so this day. Play again. Les deux Petits Savoyards; and les Visitandines.

17. Visit this morning from Mr: Schermerhorn. He says that the charges of paying interest upon loans are always included in the first expences of the loan. At the great Society. french papers. Walk in the wood. Letters to America.— Play. Camille, ou le Souterrain. Music of D’Alayrac. Les Quakers, a miserable pantomime ballet. Captain Graham.
18. Walk in the wood. Mr: Schermerhorn dined with us. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. He was out. Music.

19. Preparing to go for England. Went to present my brother as Chargé des Affaires of the United States during my absence, to the President of the States General Mr: Kempenaer, to the Greffier Mr: Quarles, and to the President of the Provincial Assembly Mr: Paulus. told them I had received orders from the Government of the United States to go to
England to transact some particular business. That I expected my absence would be short; and that the relative situation of that Country and this rendered it proper for me to assure them, that my business there is of a nature which cannot in the remotest degree affect the friendship and harmony so happily subsisting between this Republic, and that of the United States. Mr: Kempenaer appeared perfectly satisfied. Mr: Paulus said that they could have no possible suspicion of the friendly disposition of the United States; who might have business to transact in England, inducing the Government to order me there. Mr: Quarles requested me to send him a note in writing to him, which he would present to their High Mightinesses, as the chargé des Affaires must be recognized by the registers of the States General, to authorize him to act if there should be occasion. That the request for a Passport which I made, might also be mentioned in the Note, whereupon it would be immediately expedited and their High Mightinesses would then direct their Agent Slicher to come and wish me a good voyage. That he should advise me likewise, to mention the assurance I had given him that the object of my journey is such as cannot affect the interests of this Republic unfavourably. He added that it was particularly necessary at the present time to adhere to forms, and that the States General never deliberated but upon what is in writing. I replied that I did not wish their High Mightinesses to deliberate upon this Circumstance. I was desirous merely to give them information of the orders I had received from the American Government, and of my consequent intention to obey them. That upon any ordinary occasion it would have been unnecessary for me to add the information of the place of my destination, but under the present circumstances I thought it would be proper to give it, in order to prevent any erroneous suspicions, which I hoped however, would not have arisen. That I had understood the presentation of a chargé des Affaires was usually merely verbal, and had not therefore given notice of it by a note. But that I was sincerely disposed to comply with all the customary forms, and to accommodate myself entirely to his wishes on this occasion; I would therefore immediately write the note, and send it to him, as I accordingly did. He mentioned the instance of the Count de Löwenhielm, the Swedish Minister, who recently went away on a temporary leave of absence, and had presented Mr: Reuterswerd by a written note.

Met Mr: Midleton, walking in the wood. Conversing with him on the subject of Mr Quarles’s observations, he told me that a simple verbal presentation of a Chargé des Affairs had always been customary here, but that Count Löwenhielm had written a note to present Mr: Reutenswerd in consequence of the same formal scruple of Mr: Quarles as that he had made to me.— Called on Bielfeld.— In the evening saw Mr: Dumas, and informed him of my proposed voyage. At Mr: Veerman’s also.— He came home unwell while I was there. My Passport from the States General was sent for me this Evening.

20. Mr: Slicher the agent of the States General, called on me this morning, by order of their High Mightinesses to wish me a good voyage; so that Mr: Quarles’s solicitude will be removed. Slicher said that my departure for England just at this time was a subject of observation, but that the friendly assurances contained in my note had given entire satisfaction on that point. Repeated those assurances to him, adding that I had thereby followed the express directions of the American Government, although at the time when my orders were transmitted, the State of Affairs between England this Republic was less hostile than it has since become.— He said that I should probably see many of his Countrymen in England; as numbers of the Matadores of the former regencies were there; I answered him that I should probably see very few persons of that Description.

Visited the french Minister Plenipotentiary Noel, at the Palace of the old Court. found him very polite and rational. Told him where I was going. He said I should be in England at an interesting period, as the Parliament are soon to assemble, and from the present aspect of affairs, probably some negotiations would be least commenced during the approaching Winter. Told him I hoped they would terminate in an early Peace. That I understood the french Nation wished for Peace: that the British Nation must desire it, and that my Country, although its neutrality had procured for it several advantages from the War was also interested in the return of Peace, and sincerely wished for it. That our situation from various circumstances had been repeatedly very embarassing, and constantly dangerous during the contest, and that for our own sakes as well as for that of our friends we ardently wished for the restoration of tranquility. He said he readily conceived that between the opposite interests and claims of France and Britain we must have been frequently perplexed, and in danger of being drawn into the War; which might perhaps have been the intention of the British Government; but which he was happy that we had avoided; for he was persuaded that our neutrality had been much more advantageous to France than would have been our participation with her in the War. As it is said he, the English have intercepted part of the provisions sent from America for us; but far the greater part has arrived, and has been of the greatest service to us, as that is the principle article we have needed; but had you been at War with Britain, that resource must have failed us altogether. I replied that the neutral state had the more readily been embraced by us, and the more strenuously supported, as we had received the assurances of the french Government, that it was conformable to their wishes, and as we had found it operating so favourably to their interests. That the treatment of the British had been such as could not fail to excite our resentment, and that our friendship for France was unabated. But that the course of a fair and rigorous neutrality of conduct, had been pursued as the most proper effectually to reconcile our own interests and those of our friends, and we believed, that at the close of the War, Great Britain would find she had met with an Enemy able to cope with all the force she had at command, and that an additional foe, was quite unnecessary for her.

He said that America was becoming every day more interesting as an object of observation. That he had a great desire of seeing that Country, and should have been very glad to have gone there. I replied that from the manner in which some of the representatives of the People had spoken to me of the Citizen Adet, who is lately gone out, I had formed a very advantageous opinion of him: but that I should have been much gratified had he himself been employed on that mission. (The compliment was too bare-bosomed, but was sincere.— I shall never know how to make a proper compliment.) He said that the Egyptian traveller Volney was now in America, and he was in hopes that his tour through that Country would produce general and useful information concerning it. That he was a man of talents, and of judgment; a friend of Liberty, but far from having given into the excesses that had so unhappily prevailed.

Found neither Baron Schubart, nor Mr: Levsen, nor Mr: Reuterswerd at home. Called and took leave of Mr: Midleton. Remainder of the day at home, writing letters, till quite late. Bielfeld called in the Evening to wish me good speed: as did also Mr: Parker.

21. At half past eight took the boat for Delft, and before one arrived at Rotterdam. My brother came with me thus far. found a packet of London papers to the 9th: instt: Mr Beeldemaker, sent us an invitation to dine with him, which we accepted. found a number of Americans there, and among the rest General Eustace, one of those men, whom having once seen, you are sure to meet afterwards in every corner of a street. I had hoped that after the conduct I have observed with respect to him since his last arrival here, his pride would have guarded me from any further application of his. But he is not to be seen for nothing. He shew’d me his last Passport from Mr Monroe, which has expired, and requested a new one; I referred him to my brother, having no Passports with me. He is as foul-mouthed as ever against the french Convention, though he is embarassed to reconcile his doctrines with the recent events in France. He says he intends returning to America; he will certainly do no good there: he may do much harm. His propensity to intrigue, his talents and experience acquired in France, his factious spirit and I have little doubt but may be added his desperate fortunes, with his parade of republicanism, and his licentious want of principle, would make him a dangerous man, notwithstanding his imprudence, and his hectoring temper. There are occasions especially in political affairs when these last qualities generally so pernicious to their possessor, become instrumental and even necessary for success. Eustace can never be long an important man, to a successful party, but he may be a very good instrument for a party struggling.

Went from Mr Beeldemaker’s to Crabb’s, where I found Mr: Calhoun confined to his bed sick, with a rheumatism. pass’d a couple of hours with him. Mr: Haverout a merchant of this place, Mr: M’Allum, Mr: Allis; a Captain Buchanan, were also there. The former of these Gentlemen, appears to like Eustace as little as any body else that I have seen. Indeed they all seem to consider him as a burden since his last visit; most probably they will have good reason to find him so.

Captain Graham came in at about 9 o’clock, and asked me if I was ready to go down on board the vessel with him. Told him I believed it was too late for this Evening. That I would join him there to-morrow morning. He said he was going immediately, and hoped I should not take it amiss if in case of a good wind he should go out in the morning, and leave us. Answered certainly not. That
he was Master of his own vessel, and I had no disposition to take the command from him. All this rage for departing, so suddenly roused, and this threat to go off and leave us with the wind directly a head, proceeds from a passion excited by Allis. He loads the vessel on freight, and it seems bribed the pilot to carry the vessel down to Helvoetsluys, instead of the Briel where the Captain meant to go. But Allis not keeping his counsel, the Captain was informed this afternoon of the fact, and a Prince upon discovering a conspiracy to hurl him from his throne, could not be more exasperated with resentment and rage. To revenge himself the Captain determined therefore to carry us all down in a boat five or six miles in the midst of an unpleasant night. As I had no concern in the plot, I did not chuse to be included in the punishment, and had little apprehension of his departure without us, against the will of the winds. Returned to the Klein Schipper’s logement. My brother stays at Crabbs’. Reading English papers. find in the morning Chronicle of the 3d: a paragraph, stating my business to England, with an accuracy which though not entire, leads me to question whence the intelligence was derived. Night not very comfortable.

22. The Captain returned to town this morning, somewhat moderated; between 11. and 12. we took boat and sailed down the Maes to Nieuw Sluys. The Captain left us and went on board his ship. But the wind continuing to be a-head, Mr: Allis and I took a carriage, & came to Helvoetsluys where we are to wait the arrival of the vessel. Put up at Bridge’s, an English house, and tolerably good. Wak’d in the night, by a noise, which appeared to be some one attempting to break into my chamber. Got up, roused Tilly, sent him for a candle. The disturber turned out to be a great cat.

23. Day pass’d at Helvoetsluys. Wind still blows from the point towards which we are destined: blew violently in the night and the former part of this day, cleared up in the afternoon. Vessel did not get down this day. Walked, read, and wrote a little. Begin to regret that I brought so few books with me. Am obliged to economize to avoid reading them through immediately.

24. Mr: Allis went this morning to Rotterdam. As long as my books last I shall not complain of solitude. Violent gale of wind last night, and the whole of this day. Invariably from the South west. My patience is accustomed to this kind of trial. Writing in the forenoon. Walk to a village distant two or three miles from this place. Reading in the afternoon, Les liaisons dangereuses. It is said to be a true picture of french manners and morals. Received towards Evening a packet from my brother containing several letters, which I pass’d the remainder of the day in answering. first fire.

25. Gale of wind still continues, without varying from the Southwest. Walk’d before dinner more than half way to the Briel. Sent letters for my brother. Mr: Allis return’d from Rotterdam. Obliged to finish reading Les liaisons dangereuses. The book is very well written; but it is a portrait of human depravity, which one would fain hope is exaggerated. The arrangement of the work, the chain of events connected with and dependent upon one another is well executed; the interest in the fate of the actors is well kept alive with much art. The characters are clearly discriminated,
and consistently maintained. The style is ele energetic, and elegant, though sometimes obscure; by excess of refinement; the great fault of the latest french as well as English writers of eminence. The principle of leaving something to be discovered by the ingenuity of the readers, is carried to such an excess, that a man in the present day, must have gone through the whole circle of the Sciences, to understand the language of a novel. The moral and the action of this book are double; but this defect if it be such is abundantly compensated, by the variety and the mutual relief which the two stories receive each from the other. The Catastrophe of the principal male character is well enough, though a duel is an expedient too trite and too easy. But that of the woman, who is represented on the whole as the most prominent and most detestable character on the scene, is very defective in point of moral effect. Her calamities have no sort of connection with her crimes; they are such as must be supposed to have happened equally in case she had been entirely innocent. The exception to this observation, is too slight to form a defence of the point to which the objection is made. Poetical Justice, consists not merely in representing the wicked as miserable; but as miserable, because they are wicked. To load them therefore with Calamities, to which all men are equally liable, cannot produce a good moral effect, because if this is supposed to produce any, it will be only an erroneous effect impression. In truth the rain falls and the sun shines equally upon the just and the unjust. But it is also true that guilt is followed generally by punishment, and that the misery inflicted upon Vice, can be just only as it proceeds from it.

26. The weather has been this day very moderate, but the wind does not vary. Regret very much at present that I took so few books with me. The only interesting one I have, has now been read through, and leaves me to the complete empire of tediousness. The delay of contrary winds or calms on a voyage is one trial of temper. I have often endured it, and generally found it more powerful than my patience or my philosophy. There are no books that can engage my attention and abridge the length of time on such occasions, except well written novels. Let me remember in future to be provided with a better stock. Walk’d this forenoon with Mr: Allis; wrote a little. Endeavoured to read some Poetry: unable to give my attention to it. Anxiously looking, twenty times an hour to all the vanes and weathercocks within sight; always find them inflexibly fixed in the same position. Sat out on this voyage determined not to fret at the opposition of the elements. Have hitherto kept my resolution with tolerable success: but am strongly apprehensive, that I shall finally surrender.

27. My complaint against the elements was idle and unjust. They might have been ever so indulgent, and I should be no further advanced. The vessel got down this day, and at about 3 in the afternoon the wind became entirely fair. About the same time received a letter from my brother informing me, that my fellow travellers will not be ready till this Evening, and have not expected to be. Soon after Captain Graham came in, being in a great hurry to get away, but assuring us that the wind was contrary and that we could not sail this afternoon. Several of his passengers were unprovided with the proper Passports, and the Captain of the Ship of War in the harbour; by whom they were to be inspected, declared that he could not
permit them to depart without papers more regular. There were a number of passes from the municipality at Amsterdam, which being in Latin the Captain could not understand; besides which he did not admit the right of the municipality to give such papers. After a deal of chaffering and disputing, the only remedy was for the persons whose papers were deficient, to go immediately to the Hague and procure them Passports there. It was supposed they might go, do their business and return by 3 o’clock to morrow afternoon. But the fear then was that the vessel would go in the morning and leave them. Our Captain declared he could not wait an hour in case the wind should be fair in the morning, but after a great deal of persuasion, as a special favour consented to promise to wait till 3 o’clock in the afternoon, but upon the condition which he actually extorted from them, that they should give him a note in writing promising to pay him one hundred florins for his complaisance. The gentlemen asked my consent to this delay, which I gave the more willingly because I was persuaded that there was no intention whatever to go in the morning. Mr: Allis and the Captain appear to disagree very much together. But either they really agree, or the Captain has a strong check upon Allis, for the consent of the latter to stay was not even asked at least publicly, and he did not oppose it. The cargo is Allis’s, and he has been here five or six days apparently very anxious to get off; what can induce him to submit so tamely to a delay which if he be really ready to go, must be so adverse to his interests. My brother’s letter gave me the first suspicion that they have been jointly practising an imposition upon me, and all the other passengers, which every observation I have since made confirms. But I have further reason to believe that Allis is under the harrow, and obliged to comply with the Captain’s will much against his own, and without daring to take even the consolation of complaining. But hitherto I have as to him, only suspicions.

The passengers had not been gone an hour on their journey to the Hague, when the Captain declared he should sail early in the morning provided the wind should be fair. Not believing it to be his real intention, I only concluded that he meant to continue the deception upon me, and cared not what my opinion of his regard for his word was, when other persons were the objects of his promises.

If indignation were of any avail in this case, I should indulge it. If by quitting this man, I could procure another conveyance without a very considerable delay, or if by that delay I should dispose only of my own time, I would send immediately for my trunks and leave him. I believe the Captain capable of any thing that he dares, and regret having any concern whatever with him. Yet on the whole I think the chance of arrival with him, as rather earlier, than it would be for me to take another course, and in that consideration, still intend to proceed. I have made a point of preserving an appearance of tranquility and even of indifference, as to the delays I now meet with, but I have taken some pleasure in raising a suspicion, in their minds that their tricks to deceive me are detected, and at the same time of leaving that suspicion
in suspense. Allis I believe feels it. But the Captain being of rather blunter sensibility still thinks me as susceptible to his manoeuvres as ever.— Wrote to my brother.

28. Wind perfectly fair the whole day. In the morning, Allis and the Captain, made great pretensions of sailing immediately, but as the forenoon spent, I was at length told that we should have certainly sailed but the Captain of the Man of War, would not permit the vessel to pass untill three o’clock in the afternoon, because the promise to wait had been made in his presence. I observed that I was glad of it, as it would appear to me a scandalous transaction to sail before three after promising upon valuable consideration to wait till after then.— The Gentlemen arrived with their Passports before two, and the wind continued fair. Our contrivers were then reduced to a hard shift for a pretext, and it was accordingly a very clumsy one. The ship was got under sail, and a boat was procured in which Allis and I went on board. He was told before we went into the boat that the Pilot was not on board the ship, but insisted that he certainly must be, and was at the same time in a great hurry to get off, without making any further enquiry for the Pilot. Just before we reached the ship, the anchor was dropped, and Allis began to lament and exclaim, as much as if it had been unexpected to him. The pilot was indeed not on board: it was too late in the afternoon to go out; the weather looked dirty, and various other reasons equally substantial were given for waiting till to-morrow morning. I had nothing to do but to return on shore. The Captain asked Allis to send him a boat on board to-morrow morning at seven or eight o’clock. He asked him also whether he had got, he knew what?— Allis said he did not know what he meant, but finally said “oh! you mean the Dutch money; yes I have it in my desk.” The probability seems that Allis is waiting for something, and pays the Captain as well his demurrage, as whatever passengers he may lose by it. This is the only thing that I can conjecture, which gives a consistency to all the various appearances. This is a trial of temper, very different from that of an opposite wind mentioned the other day. “I tax not you ye Elements with unkindness.” We submit to the opposition of the Seasons, if with reluctance, at least without mortification; but to be made the sport of our fellow creatures and to see no remedy, to perceive the artifices of fraud, without the means to discover its track, or to detect its purpose is humiliating as well as vexatious. I am very strongly inclined to extricate myself entirely from their hands and to look out for another opportunity to perform my voyage. Another of the sweets of sea travelling, is that I have got into a public house where English temper and Jewish exaction are combined with very bad fare for my entertainment; and in this place there is no better house. So that I have at once to deal, with fraud insolence, surliness, extortion, and ill nature— Can it be surprizing if the effect of all this should be to ruffle somewhat of ones serenity?— Yet I still submit without much idle complaint.

Received letters from my brother and answered them. The want of any thing to do, or rather the inability of application to any thing important, in this situation lengthens the details of my journal, and gives them their character. I have always found that in travelling the only object to which I can devote much attention, is the end of my journey, and every thing that tends to advance or retard that magnifies to an interesting point. Human Nature too, and human
qualities are proper subjects of observation in every situation. The knowledge of mankind is principally to be collected from the ordinary occurrences of life, and among those we meet in our ordinary intercourse.— One of the faculties that appears to me the most essential to the formation of an extraordinary character, is that of commanding the application of his own mind. It is a talent without which there may be genius, judgment, virtue and every thing necessary to make valuable or even good and great men, but which is sometimes of itself a substitute for all those, and in its effects has perhaps a more extensive operation than them all. A man who does not possess it may be persuaded that ambition does not become him, and that whatever his lot in life may be, fortune will always be the principal ingredient of his success.

29. It was as far as can be judged at this time a very fortunate circumstance that we did not yesterday proceed to sea, when we went on board the Ship. In the course of the night a violent gale of Wind, from the South West arose, and continued almost the whole of this day. We probably could not have kept the channel with it and must have been at best driven into the North Sea. Towards evening the weather cleared up, and the wind came round again about South. Mr Allis saw this evening a meteor shoot from East to West, an infallible sign he says that the wind will be easterly to-morrow. But he is I think not yet ready to go, and appears to have something pressing upon his mind. From various circumstances I am led to suspect that the Captain does not intend really to go to England, and I have thought best this day to prepare at least to procure another conveyance. Wrote accordingly to my brother and to Mr: Beeldemaker.

30. If the weather of yesterday furnished a consolation for my detention, and for the mortification of suffering an imposition, that of the last night contributed to the punishment of those who pass’d it upon me. When the ship was so ingeniously got under weigh as evidence of an intention to depart which did not exist, she came out from a part of the harbour that was safe and protected from the violence of the winds, and when the anchor was again dropped with so little attention to save appearance it was in a place where she was more exposed to the force of a storm. The gale which raged so much yesterday was again renewed in the night with redoubled fury, and in the midst of it the ship parted a cable, and drifted for some time. She took no other damage however except the loss of an anchor. The storm continued extremely violent, and this morning all the passengers who have been nearly eight days on board came on shore. Allis’s infallible sign failed as usual for the first time. The gale has been more excessive now than at any time before, and invariable from the South West.— Walk in the afternoon, and pass’d the remainder of the day in writing.

31. An express was yesterday sent to Rotterdam for the broker Hudig to come and arrange an average for the Captain on the loss of the Anchor. He came accordingly this morning, and was here the whole day. There appears to be some mystery in the dealings between the Captain
the broker and Mr: Allis. Wrote in the forenoon. After dinner, saw Mr: Collot d’Escury, & his lady, two of our intended fellow passengers. But the tediousness of eight days detention on board the vessel, and the fright occasioned by the vessels drifting the other night has disgusted the Lady with the voyage, and they intend returning to the Hague. Their present embarassment is to get their baggage on shore. They have paid for their passage too, and must give up that. They are very much dissatisfied with the Captain, the vessel, the crew, and with their treatment while on board.— Sent for my trunks and had them brought on shore.— Walk out of town towards evening; returned late, and narrowly escaped being shut out for the night. Letter from Mr: Skinner who is going in a few days with another vessel. Gale continues but somewhat abated.
